title: Between 1 January 2018 and 31 December 2018, will an armed group from Myanmar engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Myanmar?
preds: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Integer nec odio. Praesent libero. Sed cursus ante dapibus diam. Sed nisi. Nulla quis sem at nibh elementum imperdiet. I recently visited Thailand and locals I spoke to are concerned about the ongoing ethnic cleansing in Myanmar and the instability of the country. While it may not be expedient to risk international condemnation, neither is it stable enough that such considerations might reign in the more volatile ideologues.

Moving down to 1%. Will that many die and more. Yes. Will they be counted/reported? No. Head of country shouldn’t be a darling of the left - she’s a war criminal albeit not as successful as al-Assman in Syria.
The military campaign against the Rohingya will do it.

With little to no efforts by the government to stop the military's efforts to ethnically cleanse the Rohingya Muslims and the international community's inability to intercede in the humanitarian crisis, I predict that there will, unfortunately, be more and more Rohingya casuelties before the year is out.
This question is hard to answer because so much goes on in this country that no one knows about.

In the past several years armed groups, as per the definition laid out here, have engaged in campaigns multiple times each year that systematically kills several hundred and thousands of people, within the confines of the definition here that would result in a 'yes' answer. Most incidents result in fatalities in the several hundred, though incidents that result in thousands of deaths do occur, albeit less frequently. Looking at internal and external factors regarding Myanmar, there is no reason to believe a change in trend. In addition, any perceived significant improvement or attempts at improvement on behalf of the Rohingya would likely increase the chances of a violent response from authorities. I predict that the likelihood of this event occurring is the same or similar as in the most recent years.
...If by "armed group," we mean security forces that have already killed multiples of this threshold.
The genocide looks to continue but 1000 in a single campaign is hopefully not a number that is passed, or even approached.

The Burmese military has pursued a campaign of ethnic cleansing of Rohingya since 2016.  There is some evidence that the violence has subsided but also some indications that they have changed to strategic starvation as their preferred method of extermination. The base rate for >1000 civilian casualty campaigns in SE Asia for the past 10 years is ~5.7%.  For Myanmar that number is 30%.  In the past two years 100%.  Given that countries that experience ethnic cleansing in one year are twice as likely to see similar levels of civilian deaths in the following year as countries that did not, that puts Myanmar's adjusted probability at 78.56%.  I adjusted that number down by about 2.5% to account for the apparent decline in violent campaigns against the Rohingya.
lowering a bit due to nothing on horizon to actually stop this or account for the number so far.

http://www.msf.org/en/article/myanmarbangladesh-msf-surveys-estimate-least-6700-rohingya-were-killed-during-attacks Article uses statistics to narrow down how many Rohingya deaths could be attributed to violence with a loose attribution to 'armed group'.  So far there are hundreds of those with most of those accounts involving violence against more than one person - the number as told could easily reach 1000. To link 'armed group' and violent death, there are really only surviving eye-witness accounts and they might take months or years to work through international court system.  There is more vocal condemnation from other countries including Western ones, against (compared to what characterized Rwanda, Somalia, Afghanistan, etc)  although it doesn't goes as far as to intervene. The article attributes 71.7% of total Aug-Sept number so between 6453 to 9865 to violence, not sure how 'armed group' doesn't play into that but I'm sure semantics come into play in someway "The overall mortality rate between 25 August and 24 September of people in households surveyed was 8.0/10,000 persons per day. This is equivalent to the death of 2.26% (between 1.87% and 2.73%) of the sampled population. If this proportion is applied to the total population that had arrived since 25 August in the camps which were covered by the surveys, it would suggest that between 9,425 and 13,759 Rohingya died during the initial 31 days following the start of the violence, including at least 1,000 children below the age of five years." Warning - this is graphic.
"gunshots were the cause of death in 69% of the violence-related deaths, followed by being burnt to death in their houses (9%) and beaten to death (5%). Among children below the age of 5 years, more than 59% killed during that period were reportedly shot, 15% burnt to death in their home, 7% beaten to death and 2% died due to landmine blasts. "

https://www.marinecorpstimes.com/flashpoints/2018/02/08/myanmars-place-at-us-military-drills-in-asia-draws-ire/
It seems as if mass graves are being discovered frequently lately.

This feels unfairly after the fact, and it happened based on the death of a leader and a change in power. Let us hope we continue to have improved foresight in other places where this sort of milestone will cause undue misery for innocent lives.

The military in Myanmar is engaged in several civil conflicts, profits from them, and shows no sign of ending them. The "ethnic cleansing" of the Rohingya shows few signs of slowing, but is hardly the only civil conflict there.
Genocide doesn't tend to stop for global politics...  I hope other predictors are right about the positive impact of international pressure.  There's no joy in being right about death.

Maybe this has already proven true given the recent wave of emigration - but i don't think that the leadership would allow anyone to go through with this given the international pressure (at least i hope so)

Now the world's attention is on Myanmar activities are likely to be more constrained. However the tensions that led to the existing abuses have not been eradicated and resources are under pressure so the Rohingya are still under treat.

Large Chinese economic interests - and the west trying to get in there too. Per others conflict being whitewashed as airhead Aung San Su Kyi pretends nothing wrong. Kudos to American Ambassador for withdrawing from commission. Rohingya have little ability to fight back. Buddhists openly racist (in Myanmar). Keeping it at 10% given likely conflict will continue to be “slow” and not hit criteria.

They are running out of people to kill, and there is rather a lot of international attention on this nasty little habit just now.  They might get going again as repatriations start to add up, but probably not--they will be closely watched until the medium-term news cycle moves on.
Already to much Press coverage of previous ethnic cleansing.

Lowering % - Muslims mostly suppressed and not much in the way of ability to fight back against Buddhists. No one ready to stick neck out at international level given courting by both East and West regarding business etc.
I did a school project on the patterns of genocide, and we studied what is happening to the Rohingya people in Myanmar. I believe that Myanmar is following that pattern.
I think it is likEly this will continue.
I think it is highly likely
After what has been going on this past year, it just feels like something will pop-off this year as well.
Though some peace initiatives have been floated, the lingering genocidal attacks against the Rohingya will take at least 1,000 lives.

Keeping it at 35%. Rohingya have limited ability to fight but won’t stop racist/nationalists from starting up again if it suits them/if they feel required. Nothing happened last time and Su Chi seems to get benefit of doubt between military and rest of world by staying completely silent.

Although the conflict between the Rohingya and the authorities of Myanmar has quite suddenly stopped (as rohingyian rebels did not want to be a reason for further violence against the rohingyan civilians), there still is a medium risk of another wave of violence against the Rohingyans, because the basic reasons (racism etc.) still exist and the burmese authorities have no intention of changing this.

The Burmese Ground Forces alone are systematically targeting not only the Rohingya, but the Karen, Shan, Chin, and others in a campaign that has spanned since the 1947 constitution. This isn't a change.
